metadata.sermon_start_end: Imagine my surprise, and possibly yours too, when I picked up The New York Times on Thursday and discovered on the front page, no less, an article about a controversy raging in the Reformed Church of America [...] For from him and through him and to him are all things. To him be glory for ever.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon treats Romans 9-11 as a thematic block rather than focusing on the specificities of verse 11:12. It drifts into generalities about 'other religions' and 'uniqueness of Christ' triggered by a newspaper article rather than the text's unique logic. It fails to identify what is in this passage that can be found nowhere else.
quotes: This is precisely the subject of the series of sermons being preached here at St. John’s this month.
The riches and depths of the vast vision of Romans 9–11 can only be hinted at in a sermon-teaching like this.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Isolate the specific logic of 'full inclusion' (pleroma) in 11:12. Avoid using the text as a springboard for a general defense of Christian uniqueness.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is a basic understanding of the Jew-Gentile tension in the first century, but it lacks depth in Hebrew/Greek nuances or the specific theological 'necessity' Paul argues. It remains at the level of a 'breathtaking discussion' without technical rigor.
quotes: St. Paul as most first-century Jews refused to come to faith in Jesus as the Messiah of Israel.
Paul uses the image of the olive tree in chapter 11.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Explain the judicial and salvation-historical mechanism of how 'trespass' leads to 'riches' for others. This requires deeper dogmatic exegesis of the text's internal mechanics.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete in its reference to the New York Times and the RCA controversy, which identifies a zeitgeist. However, it leans toward a personal testimony of the preacher rather than a concrete application for the hearer's spiritual life or the congregation's specific context.
quotes: I picked up The New York Times on Thursday and discovered on the front page...
My faith in the Lord Jesus Christ has survived almost fifty-nine years of sometimes severe testing.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Shift the focus from the preacher's personal biography and general 'religious trends' to how this specific text 'expounds' the hearer in their current situation.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is structured more like a lecture or a 'sermon-teaching' (as the author calls it). It oscillates between commenting on a news article and summarizing Paul's argument. The hearer is an observer of a debate rather than being drawn into the movement of the text itself.
quotes: The riches and depths of the vast vision of Romans 9–11 can only be hinted at in a sermon-teaching like this.
The news articles always use the wrong word. They always say, 'proselytize.'
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Stop talking *about* the debate and start *proclaiming* the word. The application should emerge from the exposition, not from a newspaper clipping.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The element of 'misery' is present in the 'disobedience' and 'unbelief' of man. 'Redemption' is clearly outside of man (grace). 'Gratitude' is framed as 'awe' and 'praise'. However, it is somewhat objective and lacks the psychological depth Dekker calls for.
quotes: God has bound over all men to disobedience so that he may have mercy upon all.
remove every possibility that faith and salvation might be thought to rest on human moral or religious or spiritual achievement.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect. Instead of 'unbelief' as a theological category, address it as the concrete misery of the modern hearer who feels 'lost in time'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The preacher explicitly mentions judgment and the 'negation of all that is opposed to God'. However, the sermon leans heavily toward 'triumphant mercy' in a way that softens the 'two ways'. It flirts with universalism while trying to maintain Paul's tension.
quotes: Paul’s vision of cosmic salvation 'includes exclusion.' That is to say, it involves judgment.
Whether this means salvation for every single individual human being is impossible for us to say.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Be sharper on the possibility of being lost. Dekker insists that traditions where man cannot be lost will disappear. The 'seriousness of life design' needs more weight.

7_christocentric_grace.findings: This is the strongest point. Christ is clearly the telos. The preacher insists on the uniqueness of Christ and the doctrine of the two natures (implicitly) and the cross. Grace is central.
quotes: When you come to know the Lord Jesus... there is nothing else comparable.
Only one death in all the history of the human race has saving power for the whole world.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure Christ is not just a 'theme' of uniqueness but the active 'Lord' who speaks through this specific text.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1850 words, the sermon likely clocks in at 18-19 minutes. According to Dekker, it falls just short of the 20-minute threshold required for 'breadth'. The 'breadth' here is filled with external references (NYT, personal bio) rather than scriptural depth.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Increase the depth of the scriptural exposition to reach the 20+ minute mark. Replace anecdotal filler with substantive exegesis.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon functions more as a theological defense of Christian uniqueness against pluralism than as a specific exposition of Romans 11:12. It relies heavily on external triggers (The New York Times) and the preacher's personal biography, which distracts from the 'recreating' of the Bible passage into a current word. While Christocentric, it lacks the technical exegetical depth and the rigorous 'two ways' tension Dekker demands.
strengths: Strong Christocentric focus and refusal to compromise on the uniqueness of the Gospel.
Clear identification of grace as something outside of human achievement.
Effective use of the 'misery' of disobedience as a universal human condition.
weaknesses: Lack of specificity: the sermon addresses 'the gospel' in general rather than the unique contribution of Romans 11:12.
Structural separation: exposition and application are often interrupted by external commentary on media and personal history.
Insufficient length: it fails to reach the 20-minute mark required for homiletic depth.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is an adequate 'sermon-teaching' but falls short of Dekker's definition of a sermon. It is too thematic and biographical. To become a 'sermon' in Dekker's sense, it must let the specific text (and its original languages/context) speak more loudly than the New York Times.
